qas.question: What was the original user interface for the 360 called?
The simple dashboard could be accessed by pressing what controller button?

answers.text: the Xbox Guide button on the gamepad

qas.question: How many tabs were on the 360 dashboard interface?
The tabs on the user interface were called what?
How many blades did the simplified version on the guide have?

plausible_answers.text: the user's gamercard, Xbox Live messages and friends list

qas.question: What were the five Blades on the main dashboard?
What was the stylized name for the gamercard called?
What could not be launched if the console had a disc in it?

context: The Xbox 360's original graphical user interface was <b9_0>the <a0_0>Xbox 360 Dashboard<b9_0/><a0_0/>; a tabbed interface that featured <a3_0>five<a3_0/> "<a4_0><b8_0>Blades<b8_0/><a4_0/>" (formerly <b5_0>four<b5_0/> blades), and was designed by <a1_0><b6_0>AKQA and Audiobrain<b6_0/><a1_0/>. It could be launched automatically when the console booted without a disc in it, or when the disc tray was ejected, but the user had the option to select what the console does if a game is in the tray on start up, or if inserted when already on. A simplified version of it was also accessible at any time via <a2_0>the Xbox Guide button on the gamepad<a2_0/>. This simplified version showed <b7_0>the user's gamercard, Xbox Live messages and friends list<b7_0/>. It also allowed for personal and music settings, in addition to voice or video chats, or returning to the Xbox Dashboard from the game.
